page_title: Carotid Stent Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
hero_description: Success in carotid stenting depends on opening blocked arteries without releasing plaque fragments that could cause stroke. We test how your device compresses plaque, measure particles released during deployment, track vessel scaffolding performance, and verify that cerebral blood flow remains adequate throughout the procedure.
primary_content_description:
Carotid stents face a unique challenge that doesn't exist in other vascular territories. The plaque you're treating is the same material that causes stroke if fragments break loose. Your device must compress unstable plaque against the vessel wall, maintain that compression long-term, and accomplish both without releasing particles into cerebral circulation. This requires testing that tracks embolic generation during every phase of deployment while verifying that the stent provides adequate vessel scaffolding.

We test carotid stents using anatomically accurate carotid bifurcation models with pulsatile flow systems that replicate cerebral circulation patterns. High-resolution particle tracking captures debris released during deployment and expansion, measuring both size and quantity of embolic material. Flow velocity measurement confirms adequate cerebral perfusion throughout the procedure, while radial force testing validates that your stent maintains plaque compression under arterial pressure. We evaluate both self-expanding nitinol designs and balloon-expandable systems across different stenosis severities and plaque compositions.

Our protocols align with FDA guidance for carotid stent devices, typically following the 510(k) pathway with substantial equivalence to predicate devices. Testing demonstrates embolic safety during deployment, adequate revascularization of the stenosed segment, and maintained vessel patency over time. We measure performance against ISO 25539 standards for cardiovascular stents, with specific emphasis on cerebrovascular safety parameters that distinguish carotid applications from coronary or peripheral use.
capability_1_description: We capture and measure every particle released when your stent compresses plaque, using real-time imaging to track debris size and quantity throughout deployment sequences that simulate clinical procedures.
capability_2_description: Flow velocity sensors confirm that your device maintains adequate blood supply to the brain during deployment and after implantation, measuring pressure gradients across the treatment site under pulsatile flow conditions.
capability_3_description: We test how effectively your stent secures unstable plaque against vessel walls without causing material extrusion through struts, evaluating compression force and coverage patterns across different plaque types.
capability_4_description: Anatomically accurate carotid bifurcation models validate that your delivery system positions the stent accurately at the stenosis site, with testing across various vessel sizes and anatomical configurations.
capability_5_description: For nitinol designs, we measure deployment force, expansion timing, and chronic radial force maintenance to verify consistent performance across physiological temperature ranges and after catheter constraint.
capability_6_description: Accelerated fatigue testing simulates years of pulsatile pressure to confirm your stent maintains vessel support and plaque compression throughout the intended implantation period per ISO 25539 requirements.
why_choose_title: Why Choose Synchrony for Carotid Stent Testing
why_choose_1_description: Our particle tracking systems capture debris down to 40 microns during simulated carotid procedures, providing the embolic safety data FDA requires for cerebrovascular devices. Custom carotid bifurcation models with programmable stenosis severity let us test your device across the anatomical variations you'll encounter in clinical trials, from calcified plaque to soft lipid-rich lesions.
why_choose_2_description: We understand the critical difference between carotid and other vascular territories. Our team has validated dozens of carotid stent submissions, from early self-expanding nitinol designs to current drug-eluting platforms. This experience means we know which embolic thresholds matter for regulatory approval and how to position your data against predicate devices.
why_choose_3_description: Our GLP-compliant protocols have supported successful 510(k) submissions for multiple carotid stent platforms over 40 years. We provide complete embolic safety datasets, flow preservation measurements, and durability testing that align with FDA guidance for cerebrovascular devices, reducing review cycles and accelerating your path to approval.
cta_description: Let's discuss how our carotid stent testing protocols can support your cerebrovascular device development.

page_title: AAA Device Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
hero_description: Successful aneurysm repair requires stent grafts that seal completely against vessel walls under continuous aortic pressure, prevent blood from leaking back into the aneurysm sac, and maintain that seal for years without migration. We test high-pressure containment performance, measure all four types of endoleaks, validate modular component integration, and confirm your device withstands the mechanical stresses of the aortic environment.
primary_content_description:
Abdominal aortic aneurysm repair presents a unique challenge in vascular intervention. Your stent graft must contain blood under the highest pressures in the body while sealing against vessel walls that may be irregular, calcified, or angulated. Any gap between the device and vessel wall creates an endoleak that defeats the purpose of the repair. The device must also resist the constant downward force of pulsatile blood flow that can cause migration over time.

We test AAA devices using high-pressure aortic simulators that replicate systolic pressures up to 200 mmHg with anatomically accurate aneurysm models. Pressure sensors throughout the system detect any blood flow into the aneurysm sac, identifying Type I endoleaks at attachment zones, Type II leaks from branch vessels, Type III leaks between modular components, and Type IV leaks through graft material. We measure the force required to dislodge your device, test seal integrity across different neck angulations and diameters, and run accelerated fatigue cycles that simulate decades of cardiac pulsation. Both modular multi-component systems and unibody designs undergo testing across the anatomical variations you'll encounter clinically.

Our protocols follow FDA guidance for endovascular AAA devices, typically pursuing the 510(k) pathway with substantial equivalence to predicate devices. Testing demonstrates complete aneurysm exclusion, adequate seal zone fixation, and maintained structural integrity over the intended device life. We measure performance against ISO 7198 standards for cardiovascular implants, with specific emphasis on high-pressure containment and long-term durability requirements unique to aortic applications.
capability_1_description: We measure seal integrity at proximal and distal attachment zones under physiological aortic pressures, testing your device across different vessel diameters and wall irregularities to identify potential endoleak pathways.
capability_2_description: Pressure monitoring throughout the aneurysm sac detects all four endoleak types during deployment and chronic testing, providing the comprehensive leak assessment data required for regulatory submissions.
capability_3_description: We quantify the force needed to displace your device from the attachment zones, testing fixation mechanisms under pulsatile pressure conditions that simulate years of hemodynamic stress.
capability_4_description: For multi-piece systems, we validate seal integrity between components, measure overlap zone performance under pressure, and confirm that modular interfaces maintain leak-proof connections throughout fatigue testing.
capability_5_description: Accelerated cycling exposes your device to millions of pressure pulses, validating that graft material, stent framework, and seal zones maintain structural integrity throughout the intended implantation period per ISO 7198 requirements.
capability_6_description: Anatomically accurate models with angulated necks, tortuous iliacs, and variable aneurysm sizes validate that your delivery system positions the device precisely where seal zones must engage vessel walls.
why_choose_title: Why Choose Synchrony for AAA Device Testing
why_choose_1_description: Our specialized aortic simulators generate pressures up to 200 mmHg with physiological waveforms, providing the high-stress conditions that reveal seal weaknesses before clinical use. Multi-channel pressure monitoring detects endoleaks as small as 5 mL/min, delivering the leak assessment data FDA requires for AAA device submissions across all four endoleak classifications.
why_choose_2_description: We've tested multi-component AAA systems since the technology's inception, understanding the unique challenges of limb-to-body junctions, overlap zones, and component interface sealing. Our protocols validate that your modular connections maintain integrity under the chronic pressure and fatigue conditions that cause late endoleaks in clinical practice.
why_choose_3_title: Proven AAA Device Regulatory Track Record
why_choose_3_description: Our GLP-compliant testing has supported successful submissions for multiple generations of AAA stent grafts over 40 years. We provide complete datasets for pressure containment, endoleak prevention, migration resistance, and durability that align with FDA guidance for endovascular aneurysm repair devices, streamlining your regulatory pathway.
cta_description: Let's discuss how our AAA device testing protocols can support your endovascular aneurysm repair development.

page_title: IVC Filter Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
hero_description: Successful IVC filters must capture life-threatening clots traveling toward the lungs while preserving venous blood flow back to the heart, resist migration in high-volume flow, and allow safe retrieval weeks or months later. We test clot capture efficiency across different clot sizes, measure venous flow obstruction, quantify retrieval forces after extended deployment, and validate that your filter remains stable without perforating the vena cava wall.
primary_content_description:
IVC filters face a paradox that defines their challenge. The device must catch clots that could cause fatal pulmonary embolism, yet those same struts or wires that capture emboli also obstruct the venous flow needed to return blood to the heart. Capture too much and you create venous congestion. Miss fragments and you fail to prevent embolism. The filter must also anchor securely in a vessel that carries enormous blood volume without tilting, migrating, or perforating through the vessel wall.

We test IVC filters using venous flow simulators that replicate inferior vena cava hemodynamics with flow rates up to 5 liters per minute. Synthetic clots of varying sizes challenge your filter's capture efficiency while flow sensors measure pressure gradients that indicate venous obstruction. We track filter position under pulsatile flow to detect migration or tilting, measure the force required to retrieve your device after simulated implantation periods, and validate that retrieval hooks or mechanisms remain accessible. Testing includes both permanent filters designed for indefinite placement and retrievable designs across the range of IVC diameters encountered clinically, from 15mm to 30mm vessel sizes.

Our protocols align with FDA guidance for IVC filter devices, typically following the 510(k) pathway with substantial equivalence to predicate devices. Testing demonstrates adequate clot capture for pulmonary embolism prevention, minimal venous flow obstruction, secure positioning without perforation risk, and reliable retrieval for temporary designs. We measure performance against ISO 25539 standards for cardiovascular implants, with specific emphasis on venous safety parameters and retrieval system reliability.
capability_1_description: We challenge your filter with synthetic emboli ranging from 2mm fragments to 15mm clots, measuring capture rates across the size spectrum that determines pulmonary embolism prevention while tracking what escapes toward pulmonary circulation.
capability_2_description: Flow sensors quantify pressure gradients across your deployed filter under physiological venous flow conditions, confirming that clot capture mechanisms don't create dangerous venous congestion or impair cardiac preload.
capability_3_description: We measure positional stability under continuous venous flow, detecting any device migration, filter tilting, or strut movement that could compromise capture efficiency or increase perforation risk over extended deployment periods.
capability_4_description: For retrievable designs, we measure the force required to collapse and extract your filter after simulated implantation durations from two weeks to several months, validating that retrieval remains feasible as tissue incorporation progresses.
capability_5_description: High-resolution imaging tracks strut position relative to vessel walls throughout deployment and flow exposure, identifying any penetration or wall contact that could lead to vena cava perforation or retroperitoneal complications.
capability_6_description: We test filter performance as captured clot volume increases, measuring at what point accumulated thrombus begins to obstruct venous flow and whether your device maintains stability under increasing embolic load.
why_choose_title: Why Choose Synchrony for IVC Filter Testing
why_choose_1_description: Our high-volume venous flow systems replicate the unique hemodynamics of the inferior vena cava, generating the flow conditions that reveal capture efficiency and obstruction trade-offs before clinical use. Real-time particle tracking captures emboli as small as 2mm, providing the comprehensive capture efficiency data FDA requires for pulmonary embolism prevention claims.
why_choose_2_description: We've tested retrievable IVC filters since the first-generation devices, understanding how tissue incorporation affects retrieval forces over weeks and months of deployment. Our protocols simulate extended implantation periods to validate that your retrieval system remains functional across the clinical timeframes when physicians need to remove temporary filters.
why_choose_3_description: Our GLP-compliant testing evaluates all critical safety parameters for IVC filters, from initial capture efficiency through long-term stability and retrieval. We provide datasets for clot capture rates, flow preservation, migration resistance, and retrieval forces that align with FDA guidance for venous intervention devices, supporting straightforward regulatory submissions.
cta_description: Let's discuss how our IVC filter testing protocols can support your venous intervention device development.

page_title: Embolic Protection Testing Services | GLP Preclinical CRO | Synchrony Labs
hero_description: Successful embolic protection requires devices that capture plaque debris without blocking blood flow to critical organs, contain all captured material during retrieval, and deploy reliably in the seconds available during high-risk procedures. We test particle capture efficiency down to 40 microns, measure flow obstruction at the filter, validate debris retention during device collapse and removal, and confirm your system deploys accurately in tortuous vascular anatomy.
primary_content_description:
Embolic protection devices face competing demands that make testing critical. Your filter or occlusion system must catch particles that could cause stroke, heart attack, or organ damage, yet the same pores or mechanisms that capture debris also restrict blood flow to tissue that depends on continuous perfusion. Deploy too slowly and emboli escape before protection activates. Retrieve carelessly and captured debris spills back into circulation. The device must accomplish all this during procedures where seconds matter and anatomical access may be challenging.

We test embolic protection devices using programmable debris generators that release controlled quantities of synthetic particles sized from 40 microns to 5 millimeters. High-speed imaging tracks what your filter captures versus what passes through, while flow sensors measure pressure gradients that indicate perfusion compromise. We validate that your device deploys within the time window available during actual procedures, test debris retention as the filter collapses for retrieval, and confirm that captured material remains contained during catheter withdrawal. Testing covers distal filter systems used in carotid and peripheral interventions, proximal occlusion devices for cerebral protection, and specialized designs for specific anatomical territories across vessel diameters from 3mm to 8mm.

Our protocols align with FDA guidance for embolic protection devices, typically following the 510(k) pathway with substantial equivalence to predicate devices. Testing demonstrates adequate particle capture for procedural safety, minimal flow obstruction during deployment, complete debris containment during retrieval, and reliable performance across relevant vascular territories. We measure capture efficiency against benchmarks established for cerebral protection during carotid stenting, coronary intervention safety, and peripheral vascular procedures.
capability_1_title: Particle Capture Efficiency Across Size Ranges
capability_1_description: We measure what percentage of debris your filter captures across particles from 40 microns to 5 millimeters, providing the size-specific capture data that determines protection against microembolic injury during vascular interventions.
capability_2_description: Pressure gradient sensors quantify how much your deployed filter restricts blood flow, confirming that particle capture mechanisms don't create dangerous tissue ischemia during the minutes your device protects the vascular bed.
capability_3_description: High-speed imaging validates that captured particles remain contained as your filter collapses and withdraws through the guide catheter, measuring any debris spillage that could defeat the purpose of embolic protection.
capability_4_description: We measure time from catheter advancement to full filter deployment, confirming your device activates quickly enough to capture debris generated during balloon inflation, stent expansion, or atherectomy while positioning accurately in target vessels.
capability_5_description: Testing through curved vessel models and bifurcation anatomy validates that your delivery system navigates challenging vascular access while maintaining filter integrity and deployment reliability across the anatomical variations encountered clinically.
capability_6_description: We challenge your filter with increasing volumes of captured material, measuring at what point debris burden begins to compromise flow or device performance and whether your system maintains effectiveness throughout extended procedures.
why_choose_title: Why Choose Synchrony for Embolic Protection Testing
why_choose_1_description: Our debris generators release calibrated synthetic particles that replicate the size distribution of emboli generated during carotid stenting, TAVR, and peripheral interventions. High-resolution imaging captures particles as small as 40 microns, providing the detailed capture efficiency data FDA requires for embolic protection claims across cerebral, coronary, and peripheral applications.
why_choose_2_description: We simulate actual intervention sequences with precise timing, testing whether your device deploys fast enough to capture debris from balloon inflation or stent expansion. Our protocols replicate the procedural realities that determine clinical success, from guide catheter compatibility through final retrieval with captured debris containment.
why_choose_3_description: Our GLP-compliant protocols address embolic protection across vascular territories, from cerebral filters during carotid procedures to coronary protection during saphenous vein graft interventions. We understand the territory-specific requirements that differentiate carotid protection from peripheral applications, providing testing strategies aligned with your specific regulatory pathway.
cta_description: Let's discuss how our embolic protection testing protocols can support your procedural safety device development.
